item.title: Erdogan Says Saudis Planned Khashoggi’s Killing in Turkey
item.media:description: In an image provided by the official Saudi news agency, King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman met with Sahel and Salah Khashoggi, the sons of Jamal Khashoggi, in Riyadh on Tuesday.
item.description: The Turkish president’s speech followed a series of leaks by Turkey that implicated the Saudi government in the death of the journalist Jamal Khashoggi.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Saudi Crown Prince Gets Standing Ovation Despite Inquiries Into Khashoggi
item.media:description: The opening of the Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday. Many prominent attendees have canceled their appearances at the conference.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: Investors from around the world gathered in Riyadh for a conference, but the killing of Mr. Khashoggi and Saudi Arabia’s role in the murder loomed large.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Khashoggi Case Erodes Saudi Reputation, and Allies Worry
item.media:description: Turkish police officers cordoned off a parking garage in Istanbul on Monday after finding an abandoned car belonging to the Saudi Consulate.
item.description: As Crown Prince Mohammed faces accusations in the killing of a dissident, Israel, the U.A.E. and other allies fear that damage to him could upend their own plans.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: What Could Hold Back a Democratic Wave? Economy, Confidence, Independence

media:description.p: In some tight House races the local economy is the most pressing concern. In Virginia, Minn., some residents blame trade deals championed by Democratic administrations, and environmental regulations, for the closing of plants and shuttered storefronts.

item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.description: In battleground districts across the nation, a “life is good” ethos may make swing voters harder to persuade than some Democrats anticipate.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN and SYDNEY EMBER

item.title: In Colorado, a Bitter Battle Over Oil, Gas and the Environment Comes to a Head
item.media:description: Colorado is among the top six states in both oil and gas production.
item.media:credit: Daniel Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: After years of fighting over oil and gas, voters have managed to get an anti-fracking measure on the ballot. “It’s really community members against Goliath,” said one supporter.
item.dc:creator: JULIE TURKEWITZ and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: U.S. Begins First Cyberoperation Against Russia Aimed at Protecting Elections
item.media:description: Gen. Paul M. Nakasone, the head of Cyber Command and the National Security Agency, has warned that adversaries are looking to take on the United States through cyberoperations.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: American operatives are messaging Russians working on disinformation campaigns to let them know they’ve been identified. It’s a measured step to keep Moscow from escalating.
item.dc:creator: JULIAN E. BARNES
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump and G.O.P. Candidates Escalate Race and Fear as Election Ploys
item.media:description: Members of the Red Cross delivered water to migrants as they continued through Mexico on Monday.
item.description: The president’s unsubstantiated charge that “unknown Middle Easterners” were part of the migrant caravan was an escalation of his efforts to stoke fears ahead of the Nov. 6 vote.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS and ASTEAD W. HERNDON

item.title: Migrant Caravan Puts Mexico Back in U.S. Cross Hairs
item.media:description: Migrants, heading in a caravan toward the United States, climbing onto a truck in Tapachula.
item.description: The American government has demanded that Mexico halt thousands of Central Americans making their way north. But Mexico may be in a no-win situation.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and CAITLIN DICKERSON

item.title: The Ripple Effect of a Trump Tweetstorm
item.media:description: Like many of the president’s tweetstorms, this one appears to have been inspired at least in part by a report on Fox News.
item.description: When President Trump began tweeting warnings and threats about a caravan of migrants headed for the border, his own government could not explain what he meant.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: U.S. Stocks Slide Amid Weak Earnings and Worries Over China
item.media:description: South Korea Kospi's index fell about 2.6 percent in trading on Tuesday. Markets in the United States were also down in early trading.
item.description: Caterpillar set the tone when it warned that tariffs on steel are having an impact on costs.
item.dc:creator: MATT PHILLIPS

item.title: DealBook: Paul Volcker, at 91, Sees ‘a Hell of a Mess in Every Direction’
item.media:description: Paul Volcker last October. “I had no intention of writing a book, but there was something that kind of was irritating me,” Mr. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, said of his new memoir. “I’m really worried about this governance thing.”
item.media:credit: Mike Coppola/Getty Images for the National Committee on American Foreign Policy
item.description: The former Fed chairman, whose memoir will be published this month, had a feisty take on the state of politics and government during an interview.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

item.title: E.U., in a First, Rejects Italy’s Proposed Budget
item.media:description: From left: Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio, Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini and Economy Minister Giovanni Tria during a news conference this month about Italy’s draft budget.
item.description: The European Commission told Rome that it would have to rewrite its draft 2019 budget and reduce its deficit, or face heavy fines early next year.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: The Bullet Inside My Body
item.description: What’s it like to have a bullet lodged inside of you? We asked survivors of mass shootings, from Parkland to Pulse, to tell us how it feels to live with a constant reminder of the tragedy.

item.title: T: They Survived Mass Shootings. Now They Are Living With Bullets Inside Them.
item.description: Doctors routinely leave bullets or bullet fragments inside the bodies of those who survive gunshot wounds. We asked four survivors of mass shootings what that is like.
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA

item.title: Turkey, Voting, World Series: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: President Trump campaigned in Houston on Monday with Senator Ted Cruz, his rival for the 2016 presidential nomination.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: New York Today: New York Today: Cuomo vs. Molinaro Debate
item.media:description: The Republican candidate for governor, Marcus J. Molinaro, left, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
item.media:credit: Bebeto Matthews/Associated Press; Julio Cortez, via Associated Press
item.description: Tuesday: A look at a political sparring match and a bagel controversy.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WOLFE

item.title: California Today: Los Angeles Teachers Prepare to Strike
item.media:description: Alex Caputo-Pearl, the president of United Teachers Los Angeles, spoke to the news media in 2014.
item.description: Tuesday: United Teachers Los Angeles negotiates with district officials, a tech-themed crossword, and In-N-Out Burger turns 70.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER MEDINA and INYOUNG KANG

item.title: The Far-Reaching Threats of a Conservative Court
item.media:description: The Supreme Court this term will rule on cases of sex-crime-registration law and immigrant deportation.
item.description: Will the Supreme Court wipe out the government protections that have shielded Americans from abusive business practices since the New Deal?
item.dc:creator: ERIC POSNER

item.title: The Conversation: The Midterms Are Getting Weirder and Weider
item.media:description: The crowd at an appearance by President Trump in Missoula, Mont., last week.
item.description: Is the enemy of the enemy of the people my friend?
item.dc:creator: GAIL COLLINS and BRET STEPHENS

item.title: Donald Trump Is Lyin’ Up a Storm
item.description: Is there an election coming up, or something?
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Attack of the Right-Wing Snowflakes
item.media:description: Jason Miller when he was working for President-elect Donald Trump in 2016. He is suing a journalist who reported on a claim made in a court filing in a custody case.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Angry men go to court to silence their critics.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE GOLDBERG

item.title: Why the Arab World Needs Democracy Now
item.media:description: A Saudi flag at the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, where Jamal Khashoggi was killed.
item.description: In April Jamal Khashoggi gave this speech, saying the dangerous idea of the benevolent autocrat, the just dictator, is being revived in the Arab world.
item.dc:creator: JAMAL KHASHOGGI
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: The Trump Administration’s Hard Choices on Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House in March, when Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia visited.
item.description: In responding to the death of Jamal Khashoggi, the U.S. should balance its values with its national interests.
item.dc:creator: JAMES A. BAKER III

item.title: Arms and the Very Bad Men
item.media:description: President Trump highlighted arms sales to Saudi Arabia in an Oval Office meeting in March with the kingdom's crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman.
item.description: Trump’s rationale for going easy on Saudi Arabia is a shameful lie.
item.dc:creator: PAUL KRUGMAN

item.title: The Materialist Party
item.description: The Democrats fail to take on Trumpism.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS

item.title: Sporting: Dale Earnhardt Jr.: Bringing Concussions Out of the Darkness
item.media:description: Dale Earnhardt Jr. at the Richmond Raceway in Virginia in September.
item.description: I used to hide my suffering. But I’ve learned that brain injuries don’t have to be permanent.
item.dc:creator: DALE EARNHARDT JR.
item.category: National Assn of Stock Car Auto Racing

item.title: To the Next ‘BBQ Becky’: Don't Call 911. Call 1-844-WYT-FEAR.
item.description: A new emergency hotline for when it’s not an emergency, just harassment.
item.dc:creator: NIECY NASH, TAIGE JENSEN and JENN LYON

item.title: His Body Was Behind the Wheel for a Week Before It Was Discovered. This Was His Life.
item.media:description: Geoffrey Corbis, who changed his surname from Weglarz, was found in his car on a busy street in the East Village on Aug. 31, a week after he committed suicide and his family reported him missing to the local police station.
item.description: A software designer ended his life in his parked car in the East Village. His family asked the police for help finding him, but met resistance.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL WILSON

item.title: Murda Beatz, an ‘Alien’ in Rap, Can’t Stop Making Hits
item.media:description: Murda Beatz, a 24-year-old Canadian producer, has a string of huge tracks and big dreams for his future.
item.media:credit: Jessica Lehrman for The New York Times
item.description: One of the year’s most successful hip-hop producers — a favorite of Drake, Migos and Travis Scott — is a Canadian who resembles Shaggy from “Scooby Doo.”
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI

item.title: Red Sox vs. Dodgers: A World Series Matchup That’s a Long Time Coming
item.media:description: Hy Myers of the Brooklyn Robins hitting an inside-the-park home run in the first inning of Game 2 of the 1916 World Series, the last time the Red Sox and Dodgers franchises met for baseball's championship.
item.media:credit: Mark Rucker/Transcendental Graphics, via Getty Images
item.description: The Dodgers and the Red Sox share big payrolls, rich histories and many players who have worn both uniforms. But they last faced each other for the championship more than a century ago.
item.dc:creator: TYLER KEPNER

item.title: Sandra Day O’Connor, First Female Supreme Court Justice, Says She Has Dementia
item.media:description: Former Justice Sandra Day O’Connor in 2012. Justice O’Connor, the first woman to serve on the United States Supreme Court, announced on Tuesday that she had dementia.
item.description: Justice O’Connor, 88, said she had been diagnosed “some time ago” and would withdraw from public life.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Wen C. Fong, Shaper of Met Museum’s Asian Collection, Dies at 88

media:description.p: Wen C. Fong at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2000. He curated some of the museum’s biggest exhibitions of Asian art.

item.description: In building a world-renowned collection, Professor Fong counseled collectors, philanthropists and curators. He also taught at Princeton for 40 years.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: The Subway Is a Major Problem for Cuomo. Here Are 7 Reasons Why.
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo helped create New York’s subway crisis, but has also won praise for hiring a veteran transit executive to run the system.
item.description: The system descended into crisis on the governor’s watch. Here are some decisions he made in his first two terms that have come under fire.
item.dc:creator: EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: Series of Lapses Led to Army Soldier’s Death in Afghanistan
item.media:description: The remains of Specialist James A. Slape, who was killed after an explosion in Afghanistan this month, at Dover Air Force Base in Delaware.
item.description: The location of the attack was a small strip of desert frequently used by a military unit, prompting Taliban militants to bury explosives nearby.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF and JOHN ISMAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Oakland Police Will Stop Asking Recruits if They Were Sexually Assaulted
item.media:description: Mayor Libby Schaaf of Oakland, pictured in March, said on Sunday she would end a policy that required Police Department applicants to disclose if they had ever been sexually assaulted.
item.description: Hours after a report that Oakland Police Department applicants were being asked to disclose confidential information, the mayor ordered an end to the policy.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: Young People Are Suing the Trump Administration Over Climate Change. She’s Their Lawyer.
item.media:description: Julia Olson on a hike near Eugene, Ore. She is representing 21 young people who are suing the federal government.
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times
item.description: Julia Olson is representing 21 young plaintiffs, who may soon get their day in court. “She has built not just a case, but a movement,” a colleague says.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: At George Soros’s Home in N.Y. Suburb, Explosive Device Is Found in Mailbox
item.media:description: George Soros, a billionaire who has spent much of his fortune in support of liberal causes, in July.
item.description: Bomb squad technicians in Westchester County “proactively detonated” the device, a law enforcement official said.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM, SARAH MERVOSH and ANDREW R. CHOW

item.title: A Hurricane’s Chaos. A Cry of Looting. Then Gunfire.
item.media:description: The note left by Ceely Taylor for her fiancé, Dakota Brooks.
item.description: A day after Hurricane Michael struck Florida, a man appeared on Pinetree Road. In a few chaotic minutes, he was accused of looting, and then he was shot dead.
item.dc:creator: ALAN BLINDER and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr.

item.title: Trump Officials Make It Easier for States to Skirt Health Law’s Protections
item.media:description: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, said the administration’s new policy “rolls out the red carpet for junk insurance.”
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: The new policy, which could allow for fewer protections for pre-existing conditions, appears to hand a political gift to Democrats two weeks before the midterms.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT PEAR
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: For Holiday Guests, a Comfy Bedroom on a Budget
item.description: Create a welcoming guest room with Wirecutter’s budget-friendly picks for bedding, bath towels, air and foam mattresses, and more.
item.dc:creator: WIRECUTTER STAFF

item.title: I’ve Interviewed 300 High Achievers About Their Morning Routines. Here’s What I’ve Learned.
item.description: Your morning routine should suit your needs, but there are some habits everyone should try.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN SPALL

item.title: What to Cook: What to Cook This Week
item.media:description: Sausages with apples and onions.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: David Tanis has a new recipe for brats with apples and onions, and Melissa Clark one for a lemon almond cake. Make those this week.
item.dc:creator: SAM SIFTON

item.title: Editors’ Choice: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: For a Safer, Easier Winter, Prep Your Home Now
item.description: Wirecutter has advice on snow shovels, snow blowers and emergency gear to get you ready before the snow flies.
item.dc:creator: WIRECUTTER STAFF

item.title: The 52 Places Traveler: In Zambia, Groaning Hippos, Growling Leopards and Mango-Stealing Elephants
item.media:description: From top right: An impala in South Luangwa National Park; sunrise breakfast at Chinzombo Lodge; an elephant family; a giraffe in South Luangwa.
item.description: Thrilled, a little scared, and completely mesmerized, our columnist takes a safari in South Luangwa National Park.
item.dc:creator: JADA YUAN

item.title: Books of The Times: ‘Nine Pints’ Is a Brisk Biography of Blood
item.description: To write about blood, the British journalist Rose George covered many thousands of miles in pursuit of the intricacies of the subject.
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER
item.category: A Journey Through the Money, Medicine, and Mysteries of Blood (Book)

item.title: Hungry City: Sharing the Food of an Ivorian Childhood at Paradis des Gouts
item.media:description: Fatima Dione, the American-raised daughter of a Guinea diplomat, is manager, host and waitress at once, and often steps into the kitchen to help.
item.media:credit: John Kernick for The New York Times
item.description: Cheick Cisse always hoped to reach those outside his immigrant community, so he opened this spot in Brooklyn, on the border of Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant.
item.dc:creator: LIGAYA MISHAN

item.title: Best of Late Night: Jimmy Kimmel Ridicules Ted Cruz for Needing Trump’s Help
item.media:description: Jimmy Kimmel reminded Senator Ted Cruz of all the indignities he suffered at the hands of President Trump during the 2016 presidential campaign.
item.description: “Imagine if your neighbor insulted your wife’s face, and then you had to ask him to loan you a weed whacker,” Mr. Kimmel said. “That’s Ted Cruz’s life right now.”
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: A Month of Robert Glasper’s Experiments at the Blue Note
item.media:description: Robert Glasper is just the fourth musician to do a full month at the Blue Note.
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.description: The pianist’s October residency showcases how one of the most prominent jazz musicians of his generation has grown into an ambassador and a connector.
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: The New Health Care: The Problem With Probiotics
item.media:description: A lot of trust has been put into the idea that gut bacteria can be a key to good health.
item.description: There are potential harms as well as benefits, and a lot of wishful thinking and imprecision in the marketing of products containing them.
item.dc:creator: AARON E. CARROLL

item.title: The Next Tech Talent Shortage: Quantum Computing Researchers
item.media:description: Christopher Savoie, founder and chief executive of the start-up Zapata, said he had offered jobs to three foreign scientists who specialize in quantum computing. He’s still waiting for their visas to be approved.
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.description: By some estimates, only 1,000 or so researchers can claim to understand the technology. Finding more could become a national security issue.
item.dc:creator: CADE METZ
item.category: Office of Science and Technology Policy

item.title: ‘Headless Chicken Monster’ Spotted in the Deep Sea
item.media:description: A "“headless chicken monster”" — a swimming sea cucumber — was discovered using an underwater camera system developed for commercial longline fishing by the Australian Antarctic Division.
item.media:credit: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
item.description: A sea cucumber, previously only filmed off the Gulf of Mexico, was seen floating near Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA

item.title: What Comes After the Roomba?
item.media:description: Silvio Savarese, a Stanford computer scientist, walking with a robot called Jackrobbot at the university. Mr. Savarese is leading the team developing the machine.
item.media:credit: Drew Kelly for The New York Times
item.description: The Roomba cleaned floors, and it was a hit. But though many have tried to perfect the next version of a home robot, no one has succeeded yet.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF
